newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission says it is against flexibility veto.
newsitem.headline: Commission says it is against flexibility veto.

text.p: The European Commission said on Thursday it did not want member states to be able to veto so-called "flexibility", the degree to which individual countries embrace new legislation.
"Flexibility is something that should be used as a last resort but not something that should be denied," said Nicolaus van der Pas, spokesman for European Commission President Jacques Santer.
Van der Pas was speaking after the Commission continued its internal debate on how it viewed flexibility in light of the inter-governmental conference (IGC), the ongoing rewrite of the EU treaties.
The idea of flexibility was born out of frustration by some EU states which felt that other members were not prepared to embrace fully the idea of European unity.
It has been given impetus by plans to enlarge the EU to take in scores of applicants -- mainly from Eastern Europe -- and knowledge that an expanded bloc will require a major treaty overhaul.

The idea of flexibility was devised by France and Germany who, worried by increasingly eurosceptical signals from Britain, wanted a formula whereby member states could in exceptional circumstances decide whether to go along with new legislation.
The decision by some states not to join in economic and monetary union (EMU) has been held up as an example of how this could be done.
However, Britain and some other countries say that they should still have the power to stop other European nations from "going it alone", something the Commission strongly resists.

"There must be a substantial number of states that want to go down a path before flexibility should be considered," said Van der Pas. "Should decisions on flexibility be unanimous? The Commission feels it should be a majority," he said.
The question of flexibility has opened up a can of worms for EU governments and institutions and problems are unlikely to be resolved before the scheduled end of the IGC later this year.
For example, Van der Pas said, if some action proceeds under flexibility with the blessing but not participation of all nations, should the "opt outs" still have a vote on the issue?
Again, Britain has insisted that it still has a say in matters regardless of whether it is participating and particularly if the issue is one using EU resources.

In Strasbourg, France on Thursday the European Parliament broadly endorsed a draft text submitted by Ireland -- the previous EU president under the bloc's rotating system -- on the IGC and the EU's future.

The parliament said it was in favour of the new idea but there were limits. Flexibility should be the exception rather than the rule, should be a transitional arrangement and be accompanied by support measures for those not taking part to make it possible for them to join in a reasonable time.
The Commission has dubbed the approach "catching the later train" in response to critics' suggestions that countries not fully embracing European unity would "miss the train".
The EU's foreign ministers are to take up the issue at a meeting in Brussels on Monday where the Netherlands -- the current EU presidency -- will outline how it aims to speed up the IGC process.
